content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will happen in about 50 minutes
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-async-foundations by @spastorino
  • @wg-incr-comp by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser
hi @T-compiler/meeting , its time for the Thursday triage meeting. Add a :wave: to show you're here!

We will start off with ~10 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow at 2021-02-05T12:00:00-03:00 Compiler Team Design Meeting: perf.lo site review
• @apiraino is now a co-lead of wg-prioritization
(@simulacrum are you going to be around today? I might want to check in with you about the meeting tomorrow; I'm on the hook to write an agenda.)
• Next Thursday February, the 11th: release of next stable 1.50
(as in, we need to get beta backports in very soon if they're going to happen at all.)
• :tada: David Wood and Jack Huey are now compiler team members :tada:

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Move query implementation outside rustc_middle" compiler-team#388
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • No pending FCP requests this time.

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Add 32-bit and 64-bit stderr/stdout files for ui tests" compiler-team#365
    • "Add a NOOP_METHOD_CALL lint for methods which should never be directly called" compiler-team#375
    • "refactor the unsafe checking to work on the THIR" compiler-team#402
    • "Distribute rustc_codegen_cranelift as rustup component" compiler-team#405

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • [T-libs] "Tracking Issue for feature(int_bits_const): <integer>::BITS" rust#76904
    • [T-libs] "Implement io::Seek for io::Empty" rust#78044
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize Arc::{increment,decrement}_strong_count" rust#79285
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize peekable_next_if" rust#80011
    • [T-libs] "stabilise cargo test -- --include-ignored" rust#80053
    • [T-libs] "Implement missing AsMut<str> for str" rust#80279
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize by-value [T; N] iterator core::array::IntoIter" rust#80470
    • [T-libs] "Add Box::downcast() for dyn Any + Send + Sync" rust#80945
    • [T-libs] "Stabilize core::slice::fill_with" rust#81048
    • [T-libs] "Remove requirement that forces symmetric and transitive PartialEq impls to exist" rust#81198

simulacrum said:

o/

Hi @simulacrum , lets circle up shortly after meeting if you have time
(will PM)
WG checkins

• @WG-rustc-dev-guide by @Santiago Pastorino
    • :tada: New members! @camelid, @igaray and @rylev joined the WG :tada:
    • We are starting to plan on working on a walkthrough section. That would be a section of the guide where we show Rust code and show what the compiler is doing and how is transforming the data.
    • There are 41 merged PRs since our last check-in and 4 WIP PRs

    Most notable changes

    • Document how to stabilize a library feature #1036
    • Note that x.py check now allows using any stage #1025
    • Add a note about UI test entry limitation #1019
    • Make instructions for configuring compiler for debug more explicit #1005
    • Clarify that check uses a different stage than build #999
    • Update logging section and explain RUSTC_LOG_COLOR #997
    • [Fixes #778] Added and reorganized lecture links #993
    • Document error-pattern header #989

    Most notable WIPs

    • Add chapter on libs and metadata. #1044
    • Document lang items #978

• @wg-incr-comp by @Wesley Wiser

    We've restarted our bi-weekly meetings after skipping a few at the end of last year for the holidays.

    There's been a lot of work around the incremental/query system in rustc recently:

    - @cjgillot has been working on moving HIR attributes into a side table instead of storing them directly on various HIR types with the goal of reducing incr-comp invalidations due to attributes changing. #79519
    - @tgnottingham has been doing a lot of work to reduce memory usage, improve performance and improve code quality :tada: #80957, #80602, #80463, #80177 and #79589
    - @mw has been experimenting with writing a hash table that uses the same binary representation both on disk and in-memory with goal of reducing serialization and deserialization costs for the DefPathTable. Zulip thread, hash table implementation

    We've also spent some time discussing ideas for the upcoming compiler team sprint which we will continue doing.
(note that we had thought, at time of our last meeting, that the first sprint of 2021 was going to be dedicated at least in part to incr-comp performance)
but that focus/theme has now shifted to memory usage (while bootstrapping in particular). Which is still something that wg-incr-comp may indeed need to help with. :smile:

Beta-nominations

T-compiler

• "Remove incorrect delay_span_bug" rust#81532
    - opened by @Esteban Küber, not yet r'ed
    - Removes invalid delay_span_bug that was introduced in rust#70998
    - Nominated for beta and stable
    - @pnkfelix r+'ed
(notably this fixes stable-to-stable regression #80207 )
yeah this seems like a pretty clear case to backport approve
so backport approved.

• "introduce future-compatibility warning for forbidden lint groups" rust#81556
    - opened by @nikomatsakis
    - @pnkfelix r+'ed
    - Explanation section is missing in documentation, causing the build errors
    - Fixes two P-high regressions, rust#80988, rust#81218 caused by rust#78864
the aforementioned build errors are resolved I believe
it hasn't landed quite yet, but its part of a rollup that is going through bors now (#81748), IIUC
yeah beta-backport approved, we need this

libs-impl

  • No beta nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No beta nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

Stable-nominations

T-compiler

  • "Remove incorrect delay_span_bug" rust#81532
    - See above in "Beta-nominations"
I don't think we need to try to get rust#81532 into stable
assuming it gets into beta before its promoted
(which reminds me that @Wesley Wiser and @simulacrum and I had a pretty useful conversation recently about potential changes for how we track the backport nomination and regressions)

(seems relevant here in terms of more clearly indicating in a backport nomination exactly what is the target of the backport, as we get closer to the point where the line between beta and stable becomes ... fuzzy...)
anyway
I'm going to unilaterally decline for stable backport
we can revisit if by some absurd process rust#81532 doesn't get into beta in time

libs-impl

  • No stable nominations for libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

  • No PRs waiting on T-compiler this time.

libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 63 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 38 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 5 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 37 P-high, 88 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.
libs-impl

• "File implementation on Windows has unsound methods" rust#81357
    • an unsoundness on how Rust handles the Windows I/O API, should be probably marked as critical. we don't have a MVCE from a Windows user, but possibly it's been there since long time.
    • libs meeting report by @Ashley Mannix: seems the consensus is ack one of the options suggested by the issue reporter (call GetOverlappedResult and if it returns error, call abort())
    • not yet assigned, @Arlie Davis volunteered last week to have a look at it
Can we assign @Arlie Davis then?
Yes, please go ahead.
Remind me your github handle :)
sivadeilra
cute
("arliedavis" backwards, for some dumb reason)
/me goes to sign up for xilefknp
If we discuss Libs Impl stuff in Libs would you prefer we mention or drop a link anywhere so somebody could assign?
I don't see sviadeilra in the list of people to assign in the github UI. Do we need to add @Arlie Davis to a group somewhere?
Do they need to be in the GH org in order to be assigned?
maybe that is the problem
lets address this outside this meeting
I believe they can use @rustbot claim or something to register that they are working on the issue.

Ashley Mannix said:

If we discuss Libs Impl stuff in Libs would you prefer we mention or drop a link anywhere so somebody could assign?

If Libs decides that someone is going to tackle a problem, then my preference would be that the issue be assigned to that person at that time. Or that they at least post a comment on the issue.
oh but this wasn't in a libs meeting, it was in our meeting last week
ha ha
I already assigned them
by writing @rustbot assign
thanks @nikomatsakis !
okay lets move along

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

• "Cross-compiling Rust to s390x yields a faulty toolchain" rust#80810
    • Opened by Jakob-Naucke
    • previously discussed, assigned to @pnkfelix
    • Note: this issue is up for grab for anyone willing to follow it up
    • seems to affect specifically s390x or to be related to endianess
    • Issue not yet completely clear, could be checked against PR #80732 (not ready for merge yet)
    • @cuviper comments that this issue could also be unrelated to endianess
I was distracted by a number of other things up until end of day yesterday. I think I'll be able to look at this today
However, the release is in a weeki. So I'd like to ask: If PR #80732 were fixed up to be mergable, would we even consider beta-backporting it (soon. like, tomorrow) ?
I still don't think that's really the root cause
right, that is true
and it would be good to address the root cause
but if we assume that the root cause isn't identified soon enough
then what?
I haven't looked at the PR too much but I think I'd prefer to let this ride the trains given how much back and forth there has been on this code (revert of a revert with additional changes on top).
s390x is Tier 2, right?
/me goes to find out
Unfortunately, I think may be a case where tier-2 slips our best effort
I don't know what that means
Shipping with a known bug
Okay, yes I think that is what we are looking at

cuviper said:

Unfortunately, I think may be a case where tier-2 slips our best effort

I was wondering last week if we have someone on this specific arch or it's a crosscompile best-effort (like mentioned with @pnkfelix )
(maybe a thought for a separate discussion)
@apiraino I do have access to hardware, but I didn't make any progress on narrowing it down
For future reference, Tier support is documented in Rust book.
Side q, Have we ever done a for release for a single platform?
like a patch?
we can't really do that with our setup
@simulacrum ^ ?
a point release is pretty all-or-nothing today
In a Tier-2 scenario, is it reasonable to expect clients to occasionally have to build their own patched versions of rustc+libstd ?
seems like that's the best we can expect to offer today, given our resources
IMO it is acceptable for tier 2 to be either not working or not available
that's sort of what distinguishes it from tier 1 :)
yeah I agree with that. I was just musing about "once we've identified a fix, what's the next step?"
I think we once had a release where ARM was known broken, and we fixed it in a patch release (with all targets)
(i.e., do we try to get a patch release out, or do we just advertise the method to apply the patch to alocal build)
Even if we could have a release for a single platform, that wouldn't help with cross-compiling, would it?
We could always backport the patch to the stable branch later if we don't uncover any issues after it has merged. At least that way building from source should work.
I like that point
anyway it sounds at this point like I should still plan on investing some time on trying to identify root cause here
but we should not be expecting heroics to get a fix into place in time for beta->stable promotion
Everyone on board with that?
okay lets move along then

• "regression 1.50: Duplicate symbol linker error" rust#80951
    - opened by @rylev
    - regression on crate utxo-oracle that compiled on 1.49 (see logs)
    - @Frank Steffahn adds that doesn't look like a genuine regression
    - @apiraino asks (out of curiosity): the crate imports a bitcoin library, the project does not seems very active and the scope is unclear to me. Worth checking when was this crate added and why? Does it have specific code to be monitored between releases?
good ol' no_mangle

pnkfelix said:

good ol' no_mangle

I guess this answers my question about why is this crate in the crater run
recent comments indicate that this was broken before, then magically fixed, then broken again
So: Seems like we should not let this particular issue block the release
I'm inclined to say its not a blocker, yeah
I don't think it's a blocker
I still want to know what's up
But: Is it worth expending effort to try to dissect what is going on: Why behavior is changing from release to release?
That is curious
It seems like it's not changing release to release, but based on the channel?
(ideally we'd also provide better feedback on what's wrong. But that might require writing our own linker...)

nikomatsakis said:

It seems like it's not changing release to release, but based on the channel?

I think both are happening, based on my reading of steffan's comments
my intuition would say that the crate graph cargo resolves looks different today than it did when it "worked"
https://github.com/devrandom/utxo-oracle does compile for me with stable i.e. 1.49. If fails with nightly with beta but also with 1.48 or 1.47.
i.e. 1.47 failed, 1.48 failed, 1.49 succeeded, 1.50 failed
but the channel dependence is present too
oh, I guess we don't know that 1.50 "failed"
because we only tested 1.50 against the beta channel
and so the channel dependence means that we don't know what will happen with 1.50 stable...
fun
I think we should not spend more time on this here, but we should plan to at least double check what happens with an actual 1.50 stable build
and in any case, I don't think it should block the release.
(as many agreed up at the top)
so lets move along

• "regression 1.50: Borrow checker reports function param as not living long enough" rust#80949
    • opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • Smallest MCVE found points to PR #78373
    • @Matthew Jasper comments that pr #78373 caused MIR to have one fewer basic block which reduced borrowck precision
    • @Matthew Jasper added additional details
    • @pnkfelix is working on PR rust#81257 to revert rust#78373 and fix this issue
I resolved the problems that were causing me to fail to regenerate the coverage logs
but I forgot there was some run-make-fulldeps issue here that was not coverage log related
anyway PR #81257 is already beta-approved
I will focus on that (and not the s390x thing) after this meeting is done.

• "regression 1.50: deny after forbid breaks build" rust#80988
    • Opened by @rylev, emerged in crater run for 1.50
    • Assigned to @pnkfelix
    • possibly related to issue #77713
    • @simulacrum points to PR #78864 and figures out the root cause
    • discussed in the T-lang meeting, the decision would be to close this
    • @pnkfelix comments that the specific issue discussed in the RFC is probably best dealt in issue #81218
    • final-comment-period is canceled
    • will be a future-incompatibility warning, @nikomatsakis is working on make it so
we beta approved the relevant PR here up above
so I don't think there's more to discuss

• "beta regression: forbid(warnings) interacts poorly with common derives." rust#81218
    - Spawned from above issue rust#80988 (discussed last week) to address specifically forbid and derive interacting surprisingly
    - @simulacrum added some comments after last week's discussion
    - Assigned to @simulacrum
    - same for rust#80988 @nikomatsakis is working to make it a future-incompatibility warning
same thing

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions

Performance logs

2021-02-02 Triage Log

Another week dominated by rollups, most of which had relatively small changes with unclear causes embedded. Overall no major changes in performance this week.

Triage done by @simulacrum.

2 Regressions, 1 Improvements, 1 Mixed
3 of them in rollups

Regressions

Rollup of 12 pull requests #81625

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 3.3% on incr-unchanged builds of match-stress-enum-check)
  • Unclear responsible PR. Nothing in this rollup stands out, and self-profile
    information does not reveal obvious causes.

Add visitors for checking #[inline] #80641

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.7% on incr-unchanged builds of unicode_normalization-check)
  • Primarily limited to incremental benchmarks; we are simply visiting more nodes
    for this check, so it is unsurprising that we take a performance hit.

Improvements

  • Rollup of 13 pull requests #81461

Mixed

  • Rollup of 10 pull requests #81493

Nags requiring follow up

From last week:

  • Deprecate in future regression #80958
    - Some commentary in response but seems likely this will not be addressed
    one way or another.

  • Waiting on response to inquiry.
    - Some investigation in #81476, potentially regression was down to a bugfix.

  • Regression in prevent query cycles in the MIR inliner - expected? #68828
    - No updates yet from @oli on their investigation.
/me gets distracted looking at the perf site
I wanted to check how bad the regression was in #80958. @rylev said up front that it was relatively small. Its more just a curiousity about why that PR caused a regression at all.

Waiting on response to inquiry.
- Some investigation in #81476, potentially regression was down to a bugfix.

looks like oli filed an issue for this
It's not horrible but not too small - https://perf.rust-lang.org/compare.html?start=57a71ac0e17e4f7070b090ab7bdc5474d8e37ecc&end=339e19697a39a78f4d669c217b7d21109215de41&stat=instructions:u

pnkfelix said:

I wanted to check how bad the regression was in #80958. rylev said up front that it was relatively small. Its more just a curiousity about why that PR caused a regression at all.

Yea, I don't think it's necessarily bad if we don't address it. It's just stange that there was a regression in the first place
It sounds like lots of weird timings overall
which I guess is par for the course on this project. :sad:
Maybe in tomorrow's meeting about the perf site, we can try to discuss whether there are other metrics we should be defaulting to in our observations
lets move along

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "Demote x86_64-rumprun-netbsd target" rust#81514
    - Demote due to inactivity of the rumprun project
    - Nominated by @nagisa
Sure?
See the comment basically. Nominated in expectation that people get an opportunity to object.
what are we demoting it to? Tier 3?
or completely unsupported?
I could see it being removed entirely, given the fact that the thing itself is no longer supported
and what process should we use for this? An MCP? Or just an FCP on the #81514 issue?
fcp seems right
(I don't even have a good idea for which is lower overhead, between an MCP or an FCP on an issue.)
This feels a lot like Windows XP situation to me, except XP was much more prominent.
but yeah, I think we can get rid of this
happy to start the fcp, lets move on.
@nagisa you want to write a comment proposing outright removal of support and FCP? Okay, great

• "Adding diesel to the cargetest suite" rust#81507
    - opened by @weiznich
    - Came up in rust#79560
    - Last PR to add diesel to cargotest was closed due to a missing FCP policy for cargotest targets
    - @pnkfelix doesn't want this to be blocked until there's a proper policy
    - @simulacrum considers a temporary policy for this case, e.g. a "T-compiler and T-infra FCP"
the double negative there might be confusing
my intet was: I want to allow diesel to be added to the cargotest suite, even if we don't have a policy in place for the general case
and I think a T-compiler and T-infra FCP sounds good to me
I'm fine with that, I also don't think this policy is very hard
I would somewhat expect it to evolve
okay. So lets just tag this PR with T-infra and T-compiler and then FCP it .
I can do that.

basically I think the policy should be:

  • t-compiler, t-infra FCP
  • we are shooting for crates which meet the following criteria (this is the part that evolves)
    * important to ecosystem, history of breakage
    * exercising particular edge cases we want to keep track of
  • we want to keep an eye on total time, which should be below X
I sort of expect the second part to evolve as we encounter interesting examples, or if we find the suite is too large
One thing I have been wondering about lately
kind of a "case law" situation :)
(but we should update it)
is having a tier structure for our test suite
where only a subset of the tests are actually tested against CI
and the full test suite is applied on a less frequent basis (say, against nightly)
but, crucially, once a failure occurs on the full suite that didn't occur on CI
then the relevant test is promoted to the CI suite
I suspect there's probably research papers on how to do this right
anyway, with a system like that in place, we might be able to make additions like this a bit more freely
oh crud the hour's almost up

libs-impl

  • No nominated issues for libs-impl this time.

RFC

  • "RFC: Checking conditional compilation at compile time" rfcs#3013
    • review by by @Wesley Wiser
    • RFC author implemented suggestions, waiting for feedback
I guess that's once again a reminder about that RFC
I think I'm the only person on the compiler/cargo teams who's left a review so it would be great to get someone else to look at it as well
yeah. but I think the beta regressions and backports are higher priority righ tnow
this can wait another week

pnkfelix said:

and the full test suite is applied on a less frequent basis (say, against nightly)

(I know this idea contradicts the "its not rocket science" policy)
to which I say: You're right. Its cache replacement science.
okay, thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! Stay safe, stay well!

Next week's agenda draft at: https://hackmd.io/xcnQ7SFaQlSzQTzZxfVfaw?view

Next week's checkins:

  • @_WG-llvm by @nagisa
  • @_T-compiler/WG-meta by @nikomatsakis , @davidtwco and @Santiago Pastorino
